data.title: Catalog
data.meta_description: Iris Champneys, forced into a marriage of convenience with the Earl of Lemister, attempts to recover some compromising letters for her sister Muriel, who has been seduced by a social parasite. Iris is thus caught by Lemister in a delicate situation, and he demands a divorce. Clement Gaunt, formerly employed by Lemister and in love with Iris, has become a ranch foreman in South Africa. He becomes entangled with Hannah, the rancher's wife, who shoots her husband, then places the blame on Clem when he refuses to run away with her. Seven years later, Gaunt--trying to escape the police--meets Iris, who is operating a tavern on the African caravan road. Iris, learning of his predicament, rides to Hannah Schriemann, telling her that Clem has been executed for her crime. When the police bring Clem to the house, Hannah--frightened by his "ghost"--confesses, and Iris and Clem find a way to happiness.
data.text:
An item in the 24 Dec 1921 Motion Picture News reported that director George Melford’s next production for Paramount Pictures would be an adaptation of John Colton’s story, “The Cat That Walked Alone,” with Dorothy Dalton in the starring role. Although the 4 Mar 1922 Motion Picture News referred to Colton’s work as a novel, other contemporary sources maintained that it was a short story. The film was initially referred to by the title of Colton’s story, but by early Mar 1922 the name had been changed to The Woman Who Walked Alone.

On 21 Jan 1922, Camera announced that filming was scheduled to begin on 23 Jan 1922, and the 28 Jan 1922 issue confirmed that location shooting was currently underway in Burlingame, CA, where exteriors doubled for England. Two weeks later, the 13 Feb 1922 Paramount Pep noted that cast and crew were shooting on a castle set at Lasky’s studio in Hollywood, CA, where a ballroom set was also built on Stage 4, as noted in the 20 Feb 1922 Paramount Pep. A suit of armor used during filming was originally made for the 1916 picture, Joan the Woman (see entry). In mid-Mar 1922, scenes depicting South Africa were filmed on location, according to an 18 Mar 1922 Camera brief. Later that month, the 27 Mar 1922 Paramount Pep noted that actress Wanda Hawley had recently completed her role, and on 29 Apr 1922, Moving Picture World announced the recent completion of filming.

The film was released on 11 Jun 1922, according to various ...

More Less

An item in the 24 Dec 1921 Motion Picture News reported that director George Melford’s next production for Paramount Pictures would be an adaptation of John Colton’s story, “The Cat That Walked Alone,” with Dorothy Dalton in the starring role. Although the 4 Mar 1922 Motion Picture News referred to Colton’s work as a novel, other contemporary sources maintained that it was a short story. The film was initially referred to by the title of Colton’s story, but by early Mar 1922 the name had been changed to The Woman Who Walked Alone.

On 21 Jan 1922, Camera announced that filming was scheduled to begin on 23 Jan 1922, and the 28 Jan 1922 issue confirmed that location shooting was currently underway in Burlingame, CA, where exteriors doubled for England. Two weeks later, the 13 Feb 1922 Paramount Pep noted that cast and crew were shooting on a castle set at Lasky’s studio in Hollywood, CA, where a ballroom set was also built on Stage 4, as noted in the 20 Feb 1922 Paramount Pep. A suit of armor used during filming was originally made for the 1916 picture, Joan the Woman (see entry). In mid-Mar 1922, scenes depicting South Africa were filmed on location, according to an 18 Mar 1922 Camera brief. Later that month, the 27 Mar 1922 Paramount Pep noted that actress Wanda Hawley had recently completed her role, and on 29 Apr 1922, Moving Picture World announced the recent completion of filming.

The film was released on 11 Jun 1922, according to various contemporary sources including the 17 Jun 1922 Motion Picture News. Shortly after, an item in the 24 Jun 1922 Motion Picture News noted that Aaron J. Jones had arranged a musical accompaniment for the film’s Chicago, IL, opening.

Agnes Ayres, Jack Holt and Walter Hiers were named as cast members in the 14 Jan 1922 Camera, and Rudoph Bylek was identified as the technical director in the the 13 Feb 1922 Paramount Pep.

According to the Library of Congress American Silent Feature Film Survival Database, this film is extant.

Less

Seven years later, Gaunt--trying to escape the police--meets Iris, who is operating a tavern on the African caravan road. Iris, learning of his predicament, rides to Hannah Schriemann, telling her that Clem has been executed for her crime. When the police bring Clem to the house, Hannah--frightened by his "ghost"--confesses, and Iris and Clem find a way to ...

Iris Champneys, forced into a marriage of convenience with the Earl of Lemister, attempts to recover some compromising letters for her sister Muriel, who has been seduced by a social parasite. Iris is thus caught by Lemister in a delicate situation, and he demands a divorce. Clement Gaunt, formerly employed by Lemister and in love with Iris, has become a ranch foreman in South Africa. He becomes entangled with Hannah, the rancher's wife, who shoots her husband, then places the blame on Clem when he refuses to run away with her. Seven years later, Gaunt--trying to escape the police--meets Iris, who is operating a tavern on the African caravan road. Iris, learning of his predicament, rides to Hannah Schriemann, telling her that Clem has been executed for her crime. When the police bring Clem to the house, Hannah--frightened by his "ghost"--confesses, and Iris and Clem find a way to happiness.
